posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2383225
I have the same problem and have found a way to cope with it. Believe me, I tried everything. Xanax, sleeping pills, alcohol, weed, everything, nothing really did it, and actually weed and alcohol just amplified my paranoia. No matter how strong the sleeping pills, I couldn't fall asleep. I know this will sound stupid and people will probably shit on me, but meditation is what helped me. It's not like some hippie dippy shit. The part that scares me the most is takeoff. So what I do is start counting in my head when takeoff starts and don't stop until we're in the air and stabilized. I empty my mind of everything else except for the count and don't allow myself to focus on the strange sounds the sensation of the ground falling out from under me. I do the same thing whenever there's turbulence - just count until it's over. This might not work for you, but there are lots of ways to meditate. I know it might sound stupid but it really has helped me tremendously. I still hate flying but I don't let it stop me anymore.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2383265
It doesn't matter, that shit does not help you conquer your fear and I'm tired of everyone parroting this shit. The fear of flying is not something rational and appealing to logic and fact does not just magically make it go away. It's not even just the fear of being high in the air, it's the complete lack of control over your fate that makes flying terrifying. Cars might be more dangerous, but at least you're the one behind the wheel. I would also venture to guess that most of us have been in a minor car crash; but a minor plane crash is comparatively rarer. Even if you think, "Oh, this is way safer than xyz," there's always that nagging feeling in the back of your mind saying, "But what if this is the exception, what if the pilot makes a mistake, what if something goes wrong." You can't conquer a fear of the dark by saying, "There's nothing out in the dark, you're way safer out in the dark than in a Walmart" or something, it's not anything rational or logical, it's a primal fear. The only way to conquer is to actually fly and make the unfamiliar familiar. Something I also do is actually research the history of flight and the engineering that goes into a plane. I think, "Wow, what an amazing piece of human ingenuity," instead of "This is a fucking metal death trap."

>>2383728
I don't just mean injured in a car, I mean you are more likely to DIE in a car accident compared to dying in a plane accident.

There is plenty outside of your control in a car. You could be a passenger. You could be driving next to a drunk, you cannot control the people around you. You don't know if the servicing was done correctly or if you're brakes are just about to break.

Planes are serviced to extremely high standards. There are many fail safes with respect to backup control systems, extra fuel, flight authorities.

Also a plane is largely controlled by computers now, there is little room for human error.

Rationality is all that matters, if you have irrational fears then overcome them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2383889
>Fly Qantas. They have never had an air crash
Qantas had four fatal crashes between 1946 and 1951. They have not had a fatal crash in the jet era. In 1999 QF1 (747-400) overran the runway in bad weather at BKK, effectively damaging the aircraft beyond serviceability. There were no serious injuries or facilities in that incident but Qantas wrote the hull off and I believe the Captain was fired. In 2010 QF32 (A380) suffered an uncontained engine failure, shrapnel from the engine damaged the port fuel tank causing a fuel leak, it also caused damage to the hydraulic systems and control surfaces of the port wing. They made an emergency landing in Singapore, there were no injuries or fatalities but this had the potential to become a major incident.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2384387
They usually don't hire directly, instead they interact through intermediaries to get experts to guide them with setting up infrastructure they don't know enough about or need outside supplies.
Examples of industries are telecommunication (joint ventures to establish mobile phone networks), transportation (installing secondhand ski lifts) or gaming (setting up multiple casinos for Mainland Chinese).
You also have a number of foreign tour leaders who are employed by tour operators based outside Korea to accompany tour groups and act as an intermediary to the local tour operators.

posts.name: NK Anon
posts.com:
>>2385591
>How expensive is it to tour in NK and would it be worth doing it coming from SK?

Back in the early/mid 2010's a 5 day Pyongyang trip with the flights in and out via Beijing, hotel and basic food package included was around 1,300 or so Euros. A longer/more involved specialist trip with travel and overnight stays in towns/cities outside Pyongyang would have been closer to 2,000-2,500 Euros. You would also need to consider tips/gifts and extra money for beer and extra food or dinning at high end restaurants not included in package, souvenirs, or extras for rides at amusement parks/bowling/water parks/top of Juche Tower.....

I would have to reread that closely - I think its just about the politics of getting him released. I guided the same New Year's trip going into 2014 two years earlier. I remember New Year's at Kim Il Sung Square we had guests get lost from the group and the North Korean guides and myself were pretty stressed out in trying to find them in the crowds.

A strange thing that happened the night of the supposed poster was that Otto's roommate had separated from the group and was out alone in the city till morning, not sure if that had any connection with the incident, whatever the true incident was. Stupid stuff like that would happen relatively commonly and would usually be covered up by the Western and North Korean guides - nobody was actively looking to rock the boat and mess up their hard currency tips or their position in the tour industry (for the North Koreans)

At the time of Otto's detention I was still a part owner but had been estranged from Young Pioneer Tours as I had started an NGO in the Philippines and was building homes after a Typhoon, YPT had other ideas for what I should be doing - more in the direction of hosting stag trips to Angeles City under a different company name. They got called out for that pretty brutally with the post Otto investigative journalism, and I'm very glad I wasn't involved.

There are some interesting YouTube videos of tourists in North Korea:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UnQmEYouTS0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HbuZlTBpC7I

As you obviously must know, it's totally government-controlled.

There are interesting books on the subject, and I really liked picrel. However, what's weird and unfortunate is that you actually have to be really cautious with which sources you believe. The highest profile defectors are Yeonmi Park, whose story is completely fabricated bullshit. She was a rich girl who was completely sheltered from life in North Korea, and now she makes a lot of money going on talk shows to tell her bullshit story. What's really gross is she's become a tool of the completely braindead end of right wing media, telling people like Dave Rubin how political correctness in the US is worse than censorship in North Korea, which is fucking retarded. The second most notable defector is probably Shin Dong-hyuk, who's more legit but he also made up part of his story, basing it on stories of people he knew, either to tell the world what North Korea is like, or to give media what they wanted.

It's all fucked up because North Korea really is probably the worst regime on the planet, so the fact attention is going to fakers like Park probably hurts and undermines actual survivors. But I believe picrel is legit, and it's a really good book.

i assume the points on the map are stops you are making?
Are all destinations locked in or just a general loop?
What sort of things do you have planned to do?
What classic europe trip stuff are you not into?
What types of things do you think you're into

Is Zurich a planned stop?
Because a cool route from Munich is south route to Innsbruk Austria, to Italy thru Dolomite mountains - Bolzano (Nearby bressanone, ortisei, merano - famous parks for ex puez odle) to Trento, along Lake Garda, to Verona (one of my fav cities).
From Verona (this could also be connected on your Zurich to Milan route) is a transverse northern italy trainline.
Venice - Padua - Vicenza - Verona - Pescheria Del Garda - Brescia - Bergamo - Milan - Turin. Italians autisitcally hate the northern cities but as a foreigner i thought they were pretty comfy but as with everywhere it is usually cooler outside the city.
The italian northern lakes are very popular so if you are going from zurich to genoa as on the map - you're passing near lake lugano between lake maggiore and lake como, both have beautiful towns, but summer in italy famous spots will have tourists naturally. other northern lakes as mentioned garda but the lower tier ones are beautiful too like iseo or orta
Are you going to Genoa area or were just thinking to travel along the riviera all the way to barcelona? South of milan is Pavia - old city with a few landmarks.
other direction there is cinque terre but will be crowded. There are many popular tourist towns on italian riviera, Portofino is a fancy one.
Like every region there are tiny beautiful towns, like Dolceacqua or Apricale - but is it worth the time getting there on a tight schedule with public transport? depends if you are taking a break or seek those things.
Drive italian riviera to french riviera is nice.
In france before Nice there are towns of Menton, Eze. This area has the roads called Les Trois Corniches

posts.com:
From Germany, There is the Romantic Road - in Bavaria, it is a tourist track that all the towns kind of have comfy romantic architecture but if you were coming from Prague - Nuremberg or Regensburg have good medeival town centres. A bit further off route there is wurzburg too. Rothenburg ob der Taber is probably super popular tourist spot but it was cool.

If you got to Munich area - for a detour, Salzburg was pretty comfy, there is also the austrian lake district outside salzburg most famous town is hallstadt,
Also in that direction there is Chiemsee - a lake in germany has an unfinished 1800s palace on an island. There is hitler's eagles nest hideout too.
South of munich there are touristy bavarian mountain towns at the foot of the mountains like zugspitze you could get cable car up that.
Near the town of Fussen there is the Neuschwanstein Castle
On your map you go near Lindau before going into switzerland -is an island town.

If you drive through french riviera towards marseille, there are the famous fancy towns like cannes and saint tropez but traffic might be congested by them but inland in that area is also beautiful. and if you are looking to see beautiful south french coast, just before marseille are the Calanques of Marseille. Verdon national park has a nice canyon river. If you look in the countryside of any place you'll find weird things like Malpasset Dam - a collapsed dam disaster, maybe not interesting to everyone but if i was in the neighborhood itd be cool.
Towns like Arles, Orange, Nimes have a large intact roman structure or two. Avignon famous for the french pope + its bridge song. Pont Du Gard aqueduct.
In June Provence lavender fields start to blum - Plateau de Valensole is a famous region. They also have sunflowers. There are too many villages in every region of france that if you were on a road trip could be worth passing through. some cool looking ones are like Moustiers-Sainte-Marie, Gordes, Roussillon, Les Baux-de-Provence

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Carcassonne is a famous tourist spot - the classic fairytale castle vibe has been recreated here i think in 1800s reconsturction.

Millau is like one of the largest bridges in the world or something.

Albi has a neat history - grand cathedral built to establish catholic presence, there was another sect of christianity Cathars that were put down centred in Albi

Going into Spain, Girona is a medieval town that is famous as a foodie destination, has some film+tv shoots there.
Castellfollit de la Roca is a cool looking village in the country, and Besalú
North of Barcelona there is Montserrat monestary in the mountian
Tarragona has roman amphitheatre, and an aquaduct

Going thru middle of switzerlnd, Interlaken is the most famous area. As mentioned Lauterbrunnen - it is like fairytale land with high waterflls off the mountains. Grindelwald also famous. gelmerbahn looks neat to try - there are a lot of cogwheel trains for steep mountains in switzerland.
Famous ski destinations are nice in summer too - like Zermatt (Matterhorn) is an alpine town that has no civilian traffic, you have to train into town.
A bit in the wrong direction but Stelvio Pass road into italy is quite famous.
Valle Verzasca is sometimes clickbait called Maldives of Milan - north of Locarno, the crystal blue river, there is a famous bridge ponte dei salti

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I live in Switzerland and can give you some tips.

First thing you have to decide is if you want to see the cities and towns or the nature. If you only stay some days in switzerland I wouldnt recommend you going to the mountains(60% the whole country is mountainous) but only to the cities, because you need a lot of time for the hiking.

What I would recommend:

>Berne
Capital of switzerland. The old city is magical, especially in the morning. Its also Unesco heritage. (0.5 days)

>Lucerne
Probably the most tourist town in Switzerland. Its really beautiful. You can also take a boat tour at the lake or got to the mountain Pilatus. (1-1.5 days)

>Zurich
Biggest city. You can do there all the things you can do in big cities. Partying, museums, eating,art, shopping. 12. august takes also the biggest open public party in whole europe part, the street parade. (1 day)

>St. Gallen
Hidden gem. Beautiful old city, Unesco heritage (cathedral and barroque library). You can also take the train to Appenzell and the mountain Säntis for authentic old switzerland folklore experience (1-1.5 days)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2386576
Those are pretty good picks for a first timer in Europe. Lisbon is a smaller, more quiet place. Great food. Rome is more busy, definitely a city that is alive, great food as well, and a bit more rough around the edges with amazing history and architecture. Venice is the most beautiful city in the world. In it's prime it must have been like stepping into another dimension. Paris is a great city despite all the memes here. Lots to see, great night life, very attractive women, lots to explore, catacombs, world class museums. Winter is the best time to visit Paris for the first time as there's not as much tourists and you won't get annoyed by huge lines in the main sights and there's less touts (which is what everyone is shitting their pants over). Also it's not overrun by tourists and locals are actually there. Spring is arguably the best period, but I recommend it after you've seen the main stuff and can just enjoy walking along the banks of Seine with spring flowers and blossom everywhere. London has similarly great night life, lots of world class stuff. Depressing to live in, but I always found it fun for a visit. Beautiful architecture.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hong Kong on the other hand is as cyberpunk as a human city can get in real life.

There is no photoshop in this image. This is Mong kok, the most densely populated neighborhood in the world. This vicinity all the way to the south feels like you're in basically Night City (or rather, NC feels like HK). Full of neons, gigantic complex sprawls with 20 to 30 store buildings, soot build up all over the fucking place.Some places are pretty cramped, but you can mostly navigate the area without any problem. Walking all the way south gets you to hong kong island, which is the financial district and has its own vibe too. It's the only city that does it for me. The other ones have their own vibe and it is not blade runner or the cyberpunk genre in general. Even Tokyo is milder than what people picture it. You want grit, go to Hong Kong. In contrast, Macau actually is a nice break since you've got all that south european mediterranean feel that is pretty relaxing. Feels like summer in Barcelona, seriously.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

>Beijing
Huge roads, not walkable, shit public transport, gray, businesses mostly in big ass malls, shit nightlife (as in, night street food, night restaurants etc). Very restrictive so not many small things going on.

>Tokyo
Small streets everywhere, businesses everywhere even in the tiniest corner. There’s always something to do.

>Osaka
See Tokyo but more chaotic, friendlier, less autistic and more night things going on.

>kyoto
Classier and more orderly than Osaka. High-end culture.

>Taipei
A mix of the best of both worlds (Japan and China), reminiscent of Hong Kong in some ways but less chaotic, more laid back.

>Seoul
Only went there in the 90s. Not very interesting back then.

>HK
Very “cyberpunk”. Very rich and poor mingle together. Businesses everywhere, almost impossible to see darkness in the central parts. Closest you’ll get.

>Macau
Discount Hong Kong with much much less life going on. Went there in the late 90s though.

>Chongqing
Memed by youtube videos. No idea why this city is brought up all the time. Many cities are similar to this one, part of the recent trend of newly invested cities such as Hangzhou.

>Shanghai
My personal favourite but not because of how “cyberpunk” it feels. It’s a city with a lot of life, good blend of modernity and (not so old) history.

posts.com: Lincoln national forest was one of my favorite days during my FL to CA bike trip. Town at the top has a really good bbq place, very friendly and tasty. Alamagordo and carlsbad are the two closest cities to there and neither of them are very special but west of alamagordo is the white sands national park and a military high frequency laser testing facility then ur in las Cruces. The gila national forest is something i regret having missed out on, hot springs and an ancient native cliff dwelling. Instead of that i went south to el paso and west from there next to the border, less hills. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Born and raised in Albuquerque (Have also traveled a lot)
It’s very beautiful, also the 5th largest state so don’t expect to see everything in one trip. Coming from Colorado I recommend you start in Taos, kinda hippy dippy place but the natural setting is staggeringly beautiful. Try to see the Taos pueblo although it’s been closed a lot lately so check ahead. You could do santa fe but that place bugs the shit out of me, very expensive and filled (i mean filled) with white texas/california tourists. If you do go there I recommend the Rail yard and upper canyon road. If you’re into history La Cienaguilla petroglyphs are cool and like 15 minutes from the plaza. I highly highly recommend the Valles Caldera, you can drive in from Los Alamos and soak it in. Stop in Jemez Springs on your way down, you can check out the historic sight or just hangout at the biker bar. From their you can either go to Albuquerque or up 550 towards Farmington. If you’re headed that way go to chaco canyon. It’s a heavy place but one of the most interesting sights in all of north america. Assuming you’re gonna pass through albuquerque I recommend stopping at the frontier and getting green chili stew or enchiladas. it’s cheap it’s fast and the vibes inside are all the best of albuquerque. You’ll like it, it’s not as shit as everyone says but be aware of burglary, they won’t rob you directly but they’ll smash your window as soon as you turn around. Park near other cars and in the light you’ll be fine it’s never happened to me in over 20 years of living in ABQ.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
nature fag here, been to NM a few times, underrated place. Carlsbad Caverns is great, one of my favorite national parks. Easily my favorite cave I've been in, only good cave I've been to that you don't need to be on a guided tour also which is nice, though there are guided tours to other parts of the cave also. Haven't even seen the bat flight at Carlsbad since I always go to NM in winter when I'm snowed out from places further North, heard it's great though, must be if it's anything like the bird flights you can see at Bosque del Apache. Definitely recommend Bosque del Apache in winter, even if you're not really into birds or nature, seeing thousands or tens of thousands of large birds take flight is a special experience.
White Sands is neat enough, worth a stop.
The Sangre de Cristos around Taos are nice, nothing specatcular though, I find Valles Calderas more interesting.
The Gila Canyon area is beautiful, Jordan hot springs is an excellent backcountry hot springs, it's an adventure to get there though, if you're into backpacking at all it's a great area.
Northwest New Mexico has a lot of Badlands with crazy formations, pretty cool. Chaco Canyon is nice too, largest pueblo ruins I think, Not as scenic as Mesa Verde in Colorado but you can walk through them on your own which is nice. Lots of other Native American ruins around New Mexico also.
I've somehow neer even driven through Albuquerque or Santa Fe, I'd like to see the balloon festival sometime.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

>>2386344
The biggest key is having a personality that people can connect with and want to follow. If you're some awkward stuttering idiot with mediocre production, you wont get anywhere.
The alternative is not showing yourself at all, but picking places people really wanna see and give them the feel like they're walking that area.
You can also fill a niche if you're from a particular country and cater to that audience. People are always interested seeing places from the perspective of a countryman.

If i wasnt a lazy self-concious loser , my gimmick would be finding the weirdest places in the countryside. Or like going around to famous murder sites and discuss the details, for the edgy clickbait.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you really want your videos to look good, get a light DSLR like the Canon EOS Rebel SL3 that will shoot 4k video. Then get a good motorized camera stabilizer that will hold a DSLR. There is a DJI on amazon for $270.

You also need a decent computer with a newer graphics card for video editing. Without a dedicated video card, you won't be able to edit and render 4k video.

With just these this amount of gear, you can shoot pro quality video. Let call it 750 for the camera, 270 for the stabilizer and 700 for computer that can edit 4k.

If you don't want to make that kind of an investment, you can always shoot video with your cellphone and a $100 motorized stabilizer. It'll still look great. You might want to shoot this way first to see if this is something that you like and can stick with.

It's easy to get views if you have a halfway decent looking chick in your videos. You don't even need to talk. Just use a thumbnail with the chick in a bikini and it's 500,000 views guaranteed. Ive worked for a couple different companies shooting videos. I learned that getting someone to talk on camera, especially with a script is 100 times harder than just shooting video and doing a voice over off camera with a script. That's how I do it exclusively now. My 3 most viewed videos are up to about a million views each. They all had a cute chick and a voice-over. Best of videos and tutorials always did well for me too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you’re into baseball at all, definitely check out Wrigley Field. Lots of bars and things to do in the neighborhood, just be prepared for a lot of drunk twentysomething morons if you’re there at night. Cubby Bear is a pretty cool venue if they’ve got live music (the Metro just up Clark is also a great place to see a show if you want to check out who’s playing while you’re there.) Sluggers is usually a fun time too, main floor has a dance floor/DJ and the upstairs has batting cages and arcade games on one side, and dueling pianos on the other.

Also, probably my favorite restaurant in the city, Tango Sur, is just a few blocks over on Southport. BYOB Argentinian Steakhouse. There’s a wine shop next door, or the Jewel just down the street has a pretty good selection. Be prepared for a long wait though, it’s probably best to scope it out and put your name in, then go do something else while you wait.

Approach the locals with the typical midwestern phrase “what up with them boys” and they’ll identify you as a like minded individual and they’ll eagerly welcome you and share their culture.

Then, if still in doubt or you find it difficult to approach and speak directly (shy), then write “Chief Keef” on a piece of paper in large sharpie, place it on the ground in large street, and spit directly onto the paper, repeatedly: this is referencing a longstanding Illinoisan tradition of friendship making, similar to drinking tea in Arab countries, or Sake pouring among the Japanese. This action will be well received by young and old Chicagoans alike, ingratiating you enough to hopefully be welcomed into the neighborhood to sample the hospitality

many cities in the southern half of europe are quite comfy in april, if not rainy, a northerner could wear shorts kind of weather.

but southern spain is generally the warmest mainland europe - and also traveler friendly and nice histroy culture, april is about the time the temps start to overtake canary island temperatures.
seville/malaga/ granada(in the mountains, cooler)/ronda + other pueblos blancos/cordoba, other less famous cities like jerez, cadiz, jaen, antequerra,

in portugal lisbon is a pretty cool town (tho very hilly if you are just wandering the streets all day), decent temps in april, not far from beach resorts at the end of a domestic train line, popular tourist hiking area also not far.
Souther portugal algarve region is really comfy, it is different culture, not too many grand historical sites tho it is cool, most of the appeal is beach/golf/countryside

it doesnt appeal to me, but you could go to morocco if you wanted warmer, and less european area with history/culture.

tel aviv + jeruselam are cool for great food, unique culture, history. not very relaxing place tho nice beach access from the city.

what do you consider far? check what airports you would use, where are there direct flights to under a certain timeframe. or if you live somewhere that doesnt fly anywhere direct that is cool, what connections are accessible to you under your cut off time frame
flying 6hours then 45min to your destination is better than flying 4 hours then 4hours to your destination from the airport also..

I dont live in Denmark, but I have travelled through Jutland plenty of times. I wanted to get a small place in the south, but it is a pain in the ass to get approved to own land in Denmark (they have strict legislation, even though they are in the EU). Also, they have some kooky property taxes.

That said, I have fond memories of the south of Jutland in the summer. Never been there any other time of the year. Between each city there are wide fields of grains and yellow rapeseed and sunflower fields.

All the houses I see seem very small, made out of brickworks. As a tourist the best way to travel Denmark is going from inn to inn. They are called "kro" and will have good sleeping accomodation and you can get a great dinner there too. I'm certain a lot of couples just go to inns in the weekend in order to fuck.

If you want to see some country life of Denmark, I suggest the TV show Bonderøven.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bonder%C3%B8ven

In the south it is easy to go over to Germany and buy much cheaper food and drinks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=lesRa92MY1Q

John Waller is still the carnivore biologist at Glacier. When I was a ranger there last summer I went to a presentation he did about bears and the my main takeaway was that you just ought to carry bear spray, which is what everyone will tell you, but you also want to make sure you can have it ready to fire in 1-2 seconds. That usually means having a holster on your waist, you can shoot from the hip if necessary. You always want to have it handy because because most of the time when a bear attacks it's because someone's managed to accidentally sneak up on it and the bear and human surprise each other at close range.

Bear spray isn't perfect, but apart from it your main preventative strategy is just to make a lot noise while hiking, loud conversation or singing songs. Also store your food properly.

As someone who lives in the area, I also have a gun that I'll sometimes carry, but a lot of the time I just go with bear spray.

Glacier is the best, have fun.

Never seen a bear while hiking but I did go to Alaska once. I also don't live in a bear country (unless you count koala bears heh).
It's basically just common sense. Watch some videos on what to do in a bear encounter and bring bear spray. Bear spray works very often. What's the alternative? Nothing?
Basically don't run, make noise while hiking so you don't surprise any bears and if you're camping don't leave food near your tent.
There's lots and lots of bear safety info online so read that instead of a thread where most people probably haven't even encountered a bear in the wild (like me).

>>2385739
I've been in bear territory but never encountered one myself.

My understanding is they generally avoid people except for certain individual problem bears who've become too accustomed to people or who are sick or starving. Other than that bears may attack if you get between them and their cubs or surprise them. So the best way to avoid attacks, from what I've been told, is to make noise when you're hiking. Sing God Save the King, hit trees with a stick, put bells on your shoes, or whatever. You want the bears and other wild animals to know you're coming so they can avoid you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm from Northern Colorado, where there aren't really grizzlies, but there are lots of black bears. Black bears aren't an issue. It's extremely unlikely one would ever attack you, the most trouble you might have is them stealing your food.

Grizzlies are more aggressive, but in general they leave you alone if you don't fuck with them. I think it's only a problem if you get between them and their cubs. Meaning, if you see some cubs, don't stop and cuddle with them. Just get the fuck away from them.

Other than that, I don't really think you should be worried.

Great emphasis on industry so all engineers are welcome
They recruit a lot of TEFL and it's relatively well paid compared to the average salary on the island, great if you don't have any student debt to deal with
Taipei is absolutely gorgeous, the skyline may not be up to standards compared to the megacities of Asia but it's a nice place with all the amenities of a world-class city

Taiwan has a rich and multicultural history that allows them to be ok with the concept of being a foreigner

>Is Taiwan the real China ?
No, ROC isn't the real china, it's an offshoot as much as the PRC is. Taiwan has been impacted by japanese culture a lot whereas the PRC modified radically china's culture through the cultural revolution. Both represent significant aspects of the Chinese civilization and you should go to both if you're truly interested.

>How can I immigrate/expatriate/live in Taiwan ?
Work Visa, Working Holiday Visas, Gold Card Visa, Student visa, and Chinese Student visa. and whatever investor scheme i can't be arsed to look up. Always make sure you consult your local Taiwanese embassy (likely referred as a taipei representative office in your country). 591.com.tw is the way to go but it's in mandarin and the landlord may not want to speak english, but facebook has many facebook groups. The price of 1000$ for a one bedroom appartment is ridiculously high. As for being old buildings, that's pretty much what you're getting in taiwan i'm afraid.

That's the point of shared rental. You risk more by having more tenants to deal with but you earn more. There rarely is a shared appartment whose combined rents is lower or equal to that of a single rental, so it's far from accurate to get an estimate that way.

It also depends on where you're looking. Lots of rental on da'an and xinyi district but they're expensive and not quite worth it. I usually recommend zhongzheng district as the go to for westerners, it's easier to move and lots of good food and neighborhoods. While being p cheap.

What people do and what i did was to resign myself to a 6 month bail in a shared appt at 300$ then i asked the taiwanese pals i made by then to help me out with facilitating me with the appartment i currently live in, that is tad more modern and great looking for a reasonably cheaper square foot.

>Where can I stay and have a nice time

A guy made a cool map on another thread.

>the problem with the taiwanese downtown is that it spans half the fucking city with many nevralgic centers (Dongmen, Ximen, 101, Technology Building, Main Station, Digital Plaza around Songjiang Nanjing etc.). So as long as you're within the city limits (even if you're not, you're never THAT far), It'll take you as much time to walk to the station than to get to your station of choice. I highly suggest living near the green line (so, the green zone) because that practically gets you anywhere and is well connected to the red Line (which basically covers the more expensive Da'an area). You could also consider living up north where the black area is. This is where a lot of older expats live, but i don't know much about it besides Yuanshan with its Maji Square (and its Triangle)

You want cheap but nice addresses, look around Wanshan and Zhongzheng District. If that's too much, you can still settle for something around Xindian without missing out on the rest of Taipei since it's not that far. Also, the 648 bus basically goes from the deeper end of xindian all the way to City Hall, so even if you're a cheap hack you can make do with that. Because yes, knowing how the buses work in Taipei will save you a *lot* of money.

>>2375127
Taipei 101 is definitely worth visiting. There's also the linjiang night market nearby too. Also, elephant mountain is a bit of a climb but the view is worth it.

Also, Taipei main station has some very cool underground malls, more precisely Beimen Station. You can find lots of weeb stuff there as well as some nice goodies and souvenirs you can bring with you. In general, if you're not planning to go to Japan any time soon, Taiwan in general is a great source of weeb shit you can gift or keep for yourself.

All the night markets to visit are omnipresent on the internet so i won't bother you with them.

Definitely go to Ximending, it's a nice bustling neighborhood. There's also the Guanghua digital plaza if you're looking for electronics. Definitely haggle if you're there. They've got great deals.

The Gongguan river park is really nice this time of year, definitely rent some bikes and go there, it's really nice. The Gongguan area in general is my favorite, they've got the best all you can eat hotpots too and there's NTU too. Also, the neighborhood around Technology building (north of NTU and gongguan) is good looking with lots of cool restaurants.

I highly recommend the museums too. CKS memorial, palace museum, etc.

Oh and definitely try to escape taipei for an evening and plan a trip to Keelung.

>>2379225
just go with libgen using unblockit (google it). you've got both volumes. workbook and textbook
You don't need a dedicated grammar textbook for chinese. You can go with the HSK textbook (for simplified) or the NTNU traditional chinese textbook. Those are the ones people work with, meaning if you're looking to be taught later, the teachers will familiar with either one of those depending on where they're from.
When you learn a language like Chinese you're better off following the beaten path. Just do whatever the people around you do and stick to it.
Also, i don't think you should care about the difference until you get 2, 3 years unless there is an urgent need to improve. They don't give a fuck about you being the Jodie Foster of Chinese.


>>2379257
When I said there wasn't any tae kim equivalent i didn't mean that there weren't any textbooks you could check out. Tae Kim's grammar guide is dedicated to grammar because Japanese requires a rundown if you want to say even the simplest of shit. Also, "the nuance and subtleties" are irrelevant when you're a beginner. work on it hard for like a year and a half, get the basics. The only thing you have to worry about is to orally recognize the fucking words because chinese is spoken very fast outside of classes and the taiwanese have a lisp-y accent that can get very confusing. I mean fuck, just get your TONES right to start with. You'll sound like Tarzan but you'll at least be intelligible.

If you're going to Taipei ? Go to the NTNU (normal taiwan uni near Guting station) library and purchase "A course in Contemporary Chinese". It's the one I used to study, and it's basically THE standard traditional textbook here in Taiwan, and getting a physical copy along with the workbook is good advice.
You can find it on libgen too in the meantime. Don't waste your time learning simplified if you know you're going to taiwan. The switch is hard.

If he’d been more selective as he got older of the types of journey he’d undertake and share, and dive deeper into very selective niche type of travel he could’ve been a true legend of the travel writing/journal genre, but he sold out and will only ever be a contender in history.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2384884
I think you misunderstand the entire suburb conversation.

It isn't about the fact that edges of cities will have predominantly residential zoning, it's that in America (and this stretches into Canada) we have the phenomenon of developer corporations (e.g. Mattamy homes) creating fake suburban neighbourhoods from scratch in a specific, awful way. This involves dumping cookie-cutter single-family houses, all of the same design, with zero utilities or commercial/retail/industrial space within walking distance. This creates essentially an open-air prison entirely dependent on the urban metropolis for support. You may see my original post for a photographic example.

Compare with a landscape where there is no globohomo developer corporation mass-building suburbs - i.e. continental Europe. In these suburbs, each land lot is owned by a separate property owner who builds his own house or industrial/commercial space.This flexibility allows for a flourishing of industry (in picrel, of suburbs of Kraków, you can see at least 3 separate businesses) and encourages self-sufficiency and a feeling of natural rootedness. And of course, this creates uniqueness in that every property is just a little bit different from its neighbour.

You're wrong. You can get a room in Seville for like $400 a month, I know someone who is doing this. It's a nice college town, young sluts come from all over Europe on Erasmus.

If a Latino immigrant making 10€/hr picking strawberries can make it in Spain, you can too, ffs. You could get a room in a tier-one city like Madrid for like 700 bucks.

You just have to know where to look for an apartment. Don't use AirBnb for anything other than the short term. Go on local Facebook groups and ask where to get started looking.

If people find out you have a remote American income they'll be lining up to rent to you. I met a Brazilian guy willing to rent to me for $40 a night at the height of the tourist season in Barcelona. If you looked online you'd hardly be able to find anything for less than $200, if you were able to find anything at all. Wasn't a bad part of town either, even though in Spain "the bad part of town" is an absolute joke in terms of danger compared to the US, Latin America, France, etc.

You do have to be aware of scams. If a nigger starts video calling you asking for a deposit on a place you haven't been to, don't give him anything.

I've found that Spain is a nice middle ground for someone looking to live large on a remote income. It's a safe, clean white country that is full of attractive women, very cosmopolitan with a vast cultural wealth at the same time. The nightlife is out of this world. I was able to eat out twice a day and get drunk every night when I went, and I make less than $100k. Yes, it's difficult if you depend on the local economy to make a living, but if you make your money abroad it's an option that is definitely worth considering.

Check several airlines, one anon pointed out Norse, it's a good option if you're that broke but remember, you're not going to have food nor a bag, last year i found a Paris-JFK for 300 dollars round with Delta but it was a flash offer, so as long as you check frequently, even severals times every day, you might find a flash deal or even an error fare (Really uncommon, and the airline will probably refund you)
Also, DO NOT boom through third-party resellers, it might be marginally cheaper, but once you have trouble, you will wish that you had booked directly instead
Skyscanner and Skiplagged are your best friends, leave a price alert so you might get a good deal at one point

I have been here for almost 2 weeks now, first time in LATAM and North America (I’m Australian) went to CDMX for 6 days which was a blast (stayed in La Condesa) and have been driving around Yucatán for the past 6 days, got another 5 nights in Tulum and Cancun which are the only real resort style legs of the trip.

Honestly me and my gf (who had never really left Aus/NZ and is pretty naive when it comes to travel/street smarts) have felt perfectly safe the whole time, including walking around at night. The Mexican people have also been really nice and welcoming. The only times I felt slightly dodgy were around La Merced and on the northern edge of the Centro Histórico towards Tepito in Mexico City, and even then I was only worried about being pickpocketed not mugged or anything. Yucatán has felt extremely safe, even driving has been fine - first time driving on the RHS of the road for me - just have to embrace that the road rules are a bit more “maleable” than the West.

I can’t speak for the whole country obviously but don’t let its reputation put you off.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2385055
Hotel. Was probably about $200 AUD (~$140USD) a night for the room, but that was a pretty nice hotel in a good area over the Christmas/NY period. I’m sure you can get something very decent for 50-100 USD in a good area. We probably spent about a hundred bucks a day on food, activities, getting around etc. But that was getting taxis and Ubers instead of the metro. The metro is dirt cheap (like 5 pesos a ride) and is pretty extensive. There is a bunch of street food in CDMX and you can get some good stuff for a few dollars, or if you prefer restaurants there is literally one every 50m in the Condesa/Roma areas and you can get a really nice meal for $10-20. I wasn’t exactly worried about money on this trip so I am spending a lot more than I normally would, but I would say $50USD per day would be plenty for food, transport, seeing a few museums etc. Depending on how cheap you are willing to go I reckon you could get away with $50 a day total if you are willing to stay in hostels or whatever.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378776
This sounds about right.

You can make India as cheap or as expensive as you'd like. Personally, I think $50-60 per day is a good range for travelers who want to be reasonably comfortable and not have to constantly pinch pennies.

For about $50-60 per day, you can get:
>reasonably nice hotel room (2-3 stars) or Airbnb
>mix of street food and mid-range restaurant food
>private and public transportation (Uber+Metro)
>enough money to have a few drinks in the evening or on the weekends
>money for entrance fees and general sightseeing
>souvenirs and okay-quality handicrafts

You can obviously survive on much, much less money. If you're staying in a hostel dorm, for instance, you probably don't need more than $20-25 per day, assuming the dorm bed costs $8-10.

Fuck--you can basically live on $1-5 per day if you Couchsurf/stay in mosques/stay in gurudwaras and only eat street food. It's fucking India, most people outside of big cities are living on like $2-3 per day. Just don't expect that you can maintain a comfortable standard of living on these sorts of budgets.

However, I do think any strict budget of less than $20 per day is going to entail some significant sacrifices, especially for people who want to do adventure sports, visit a lot of monuments, etc. When you're spending closer to $50-60+ per day, you won't have the budget to stay in a 4- or 5-star hotel, but you can do pretty much everything else without having to think twice about your finances (within reason, of course).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378901
As a quick follow-up, if you're traveling in the country, money obviously goes a lot further. I regularly travel to East-Central India and stay in homestays. In one of the villages I frequent, there are like 2-3 different homestays. The rates are like:
>$7-8 per night for an entire mud house (sounds primitive but actually p comfortable)
>$3-4 per day for food (3 meals per day)
>$8-9 for a guide / someone to drive you around wherever you want (not necessary, but helpful if you want to visit hardcore ooga-booga areas etc)
>$3-4 per day for motorbike, fuel separate (I usually take my own bike)

so for about $20-30 per day, you have accommodation, transportation, and food completely covered

also worth bearing in mind that a lot of dirt-cheap hotels simply do not accept foreign guests, especially in smaller cities in rural areas. this has much less to do with xenophobia than local law, which requires anyone hosting a foreign national to submit a report (Form C) to law enforcement within 24 hours of the guest's arrival. most hotels just don't want to bother, since you have to create an account on the e-FRRO website and it takes like 10-20 minutes on a shitty internet connection to enter all the info

ofc, it's still india so you can accomplish just about anything with the right amount of money + patience

probably the sleepiest country i've ever visited. amman is just strange because of the absurd urban sprawl (bc of some building height regulation, i heard?). found it very difficult to keep interested there for any real time, i think if the world cup wasn't on while i was there i would've had some real trouble in finding things to do. royal car museum is cool to and got to see my favourite car ever (slr stirling moss), albeit in an ugly color. petra itself is ok but absurdly expensive compared to other similar attractions worldwide, and wadi musa is shit bc the locals there are all disgusting fucking thieves. i understand the tourist price inflation, but when they tell you with a straight face that a water and twix is 9 dollars just because they see you're foreign, it can all fuck off.

if you don't speak any arabic (luckily i do a little to avoid/call out things such as above), you'll do nothing but have money extracted from you in jordan. departure tax if you leave by land (dk about airports), they charge you to take the mandatory bus between border checkpoints as well as charging you per bag, etc. currency is absurdly pegged and doesn't convert properly when you pay by card so that'll fuck you too. the northwest near leb is quite nice apparently, though.

Sure they can be nice if your vacation consists of wanting to just laze around the hotel for 20hrs a day but at that point why fucking travel? IMO it's like flying business or first on a plane, has it's usefulness and benefits but often so not worth the price unless it's like your one get away of the year.

That sort of service is very, very welcome if you go outside of 1st world as all bullshit is handled by the hotel.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My taste became a lot more bourgeois when I got married—my wife has higher standards for comfort than I do, and we have enough money now that semi-expensive hotels aren’t a problem for us. I wouldn’t enjoy spending $1000+/night, but I can’t remember the last time we spent less than $200 except in developing countries, and in expensive cities we have very often spent a lot more than that.

I have vivid memories of the moment my perspective shifted, back when I was still a young poor cheapskate backpacker. My now-wife insisted we move out of the <$10/night concrete cell with the bare lightbulb hanging from the ceiling that I had found for us in Thailand, and into the (maybe as much as $40/night?) hotel across the street. Fine, I admit it, yeah, this bed isn’t hard as a rock, and the lighting isn’t dismal, and it looks cleaner, and the hot shower and air-con do actually make me noticeably more comfortable. Better hotel wins.

A similar logic applies to how we use hotels now. Spending more than the cheapest price available guarantees at least somewhat, sometimes far, better comfort and details. But eventually there’s a diminishing return in my opinion—most midrange/4-star/business hotels are totally boring, especially chains, and the luxuries you get in 5-star++ places and resorts can be fun for novelty or a special treat, but seem stupid to insist on. Most luxury amenities, maybe apart from fancy-pants showers and baths and high-end bathrobes that are guaranteed to actually be clean, are wasted on me personally.

If you’re young and poor it can be a blast to splurge on a higher-end hotel and pretend to be rich for a few days. But as someone who is now old and sort of rich, I find that I get my favorite results from interesting smaller guesthouses or boutique hotels that are neither the most economical nor the most expensive.

It's only worth it if you are using everything the hotel has to offer, eg private pools, bars, spas, casino, restraunts, room service etc.

Dont do it with kids, I never really appreciated it or cared.
Dont do it if you are deciding between 5k on a nice hotel for 2-3 nights, or some awesome private tour/ experience you really want to do. Do the tour.
Glamping is a meme. Bar some African ones where if you dont see the big game you came to see you get money back.
Once a year I spend about 10k on a hotel for the weekend. Its good 3-4 days of peace and quiet, massages, cocktails by the pool, great food, some kind of entertainment,
I'd suggest trying it it poor countries as 5 star expensive hotels there are cheaper than something like NY.

>>2379865
Recently went to both a 5-star hotel and a big chain hotel (Hyatt) for the first time in my life
Being used to airbnbs and cheaper 2-3 star hotels, the service surprised me greatly on both, i'd say that the Hyatt service was miles better but it was probably because the lady at the desk was actually from my home region
The 5-star hotel had great views, and lots of amenities like spa, pool and gym that i promptly ignored to instead walk around the city i was staying, while the Hyatt was just to sleep before taking a flight (And damn what a great bed)
Was is worth it on both cases? Yes
Would i book again on a 5-star hotel? Maybe not, unless i get an insane deal like i got this time (Off-season plus reserved through the visa luxury hotel website, got two nights on a suite plus free breakfast for the same price as one night on a lower room tier without breakfast on the hotel website)
Should you spend that much money on either a 5-star hotel or a big chain hotel? If you can, of course, you pay for the service and what the hotel offers to you, it might make more sense to stay on a 4-star or even a 3-star hotel, but the sheer luxury of a 5-star luxury hotel or even the name of a chain hotel means that you can be sure that you're going to receive quality, and if you don't, they'll make sure you do to keep either the five stars or the name that backs them up

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.
